text.p: Consider the list of vectors [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline], where

Can you find scalars [mathjaxinline]a_1, a_2, a_3[/mathjaxinline], not all zero, such that [mathjaxinline]a_1v_1 + a_2 v_2 + a_3 v_3 = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline]? If so, enter an example of such scalars below. (Use decimals only, separated by commas. For instance, enter 3,2,5 if you want [mathjaxinline]a_1 = 3, a_2=2, a_3=5[/mathjaxinline].) If not, enter ‘No'.
Is the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] linearly dependent or linearly independent?

font.p: The first answer is immediately "yes" because we have the zero vector in our set; we can choose any non-zero value for [mathjaxinline]a_2[/mathjaxinline], and with [mathjaxinline]a_1 = 0[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a_3 = 0[/mathjaxinline], the above equation will still be true. Because there exist sets of coefficients, not all zero, that make the above equation true, the list [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly dependent.
